ratings.comment: similar report as other classes; professor often made his grad student teach, and wasn't particularly more clear than the book at explaining the material (which he followed exactly at a slow pace). Selected homework on the spot in class from the easiest problems in the section. Exams were a regurgitation of the book and homework. Ended up skipping.

Prof. Chen went to class probably less than I did. He was always at least 5 minutes late, or he had his grad students teach for him. Homework was never collected, he didn't understand the material, and because of his poor teaching skills, the grader gave everyone at least a BC. I like him, he's a nice, jolly guy, but he is a poor teacher.
he copys from the book. Exams are sometime exactly the same as the text . I went to lecture once. He is soooo disorganized. But If you do your homework and memorize the textbook you will be just fine
No point in going to lecture. Homework was harder than  the exams. I got an A by going through the examples in the textbook before exams and that was it.
I swear this man bathes in chalk...Lectures are pretty rough and the linear algebra stuff is true.  Tests aren't terrible but a little tricky.  Read the book and it's not too bad.

He derives proofs and may do a few examples, which he pulls strait out of the book. I stopped going to lecture because I might as well just read the book. Otherwise, he's a humorous good hearted guy who doesn't really care that much about teaching us linear algebra.

His speaks softly and with a heavy accent.  Copies out of the book.  Tells random stories.  Is covered in chalk at the end of lecture.  At times can't comprehend questions from students.  Seems to think math 340 is a prerequisite and expects students to understand linear algebra.  Read the book and do the hw and you'll do fine.
Somewhat disorganized. Lecures consist of directly copying examples from the text onto the board.  Sleep through lecture, and read the text instead.

Get in the habit of reading the book; it's the only way to learn this stuff. Tests are often very similar to the homework (which is graded). His english is not the best and his lecture style is confusing (which he openly admits to). He goes into long comparisons between the US and China, and he makes a lot of bizarre jokes that no one gets.
